etymologies: Old English (in an earlier sense). From tithing + man

definitions: In Anglo-Saxon and later medieval England: the chief member of a tithing in a system of frank-pledge. Later: a parish officer having the same role and function as a petty constable. Compare headborough.
(originally colonial). Also tidingman. In Maryland and New England: an elected officer of a township, having the same role and function as a petty constable.

notes.text: In New England, the chief function of the tithingman came to be that of enforcing observance of the Sabbath and good behaviour during church services.
